summary: the exact mutations and mechanisms of host shifting have been studied in emerging zoonotic viruses such as influenza virus, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and Ebola virus (7, 8). these viruses are capable of generating and maintaining substantial genetic variation (11, 12) this variation fuels adaptation, and selective sweeps leave genetic marks of past ecological history in viral genomes. this kind of serial emergence allows for the possibility of host range mutations themselves to play a significant role in shaping the landscape of further emergence. the model RNA virus Pseudomonas double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) bacteriophage 6 investigated the role of extant host range mutations on further host range expansion. DISCUSSION Epistasis plays a large role in viral evolution. 6-WT was grown on the highly productive host P. syringae pv. phaseolicola. the two mutants could not be grown on P. syringae pv. phaseolicola without risking reversion of their P. syringae pv. tomato host range mutations. descendants would face identical constraints when infecting the P. syringae pv. atrofaciens host. this is one of few (or the only) P. syringae pv. atrofaciens host range mutations in P3 that improves the mutant’s P3 structure and function. nes in the 6-G515S population reverting (S515G) while fixing a P. syringae pv. atrofaciens host range mutation. this suggests that the G515S mutation is a relatively deleterious mutation to maintain in the genome when it is not grown on P. syringae pv. phaseolicola. for 6-WT, 10 of the 13 clones that did not have a mutation in P3 had one of five nonsynonymous mutations in P12. this would require 6-WT to be able to attach and infect P. syringae pv. atrofaciens but fail to show its infection through a plaque assay. then mutations in a number of genes could boost the infectivity of 6 to cause successful plaque formation. pv. atrofaciens host range-associated mutations in p12, p9, or p5 may prove useful as a small segment marker for genetic crosses in 6. existing mutational markers on the small segment are an easily reverted temperature sensitivity and an unstable genetic insertion (61, 62). the top three most frequently observed P3 mutations in 6-WT showed the largest change in entropy. this pattern does not apply to other observed host range mutations. membrane protein P9, enveloped lytic protein P5 and membrane morphogenic protein P12 are known to affect 6 thermal niche expansion (44) it is not uncommon for nonstructural genes that are not on the exterior of the virion to be a host range determinant. it is rarer for nonstructural genes that are not on the exterior of the virion to be a host range determinant. 6-WT on hosts closely
